docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Joshua Sparrow, a child psychiatrist with the Brazelton Touchpoints Center at Children's Hospital in Boston, recently responded to reader questions about children and the stress of the holiday season.

headline.main: A Child Psychiatrist Talks About Autism

docs.abstract: Dr. Joshua Sparrow of the Brazelton Touchpoints Center responds to readers' questions about autism and sensory processing disorder.
docs.snippet: Dr. Joshua Sparrow of the Brazelton Touchpoints Center responds to readers' questions about autism and sensory processing disorder.

docs.lead_paragraph: I wonder periodically if there is some sort of mom-blog jinx. I was already an avid reader of blogs even before I was asked to create Motherlode, and now scrolling through several dozen of them each day is my professional routine. When you read so many you can't help noticing that very bad things have happened to a striking number of their authors. Some of this, of course, is because the Internet is now the place to turn when parents are struggling. That would explain many of the blogs that were started after -- after a father was paralyzed, or a mother died in childbirth or a husband drowned.But what strikes me is the number of times that tragedy found a blogger who just happened to be blogging. Stephanie Nielsen wrote mostly about life as the mother of four children until she and her husband were nearly killed, and Stephanie was horrifyingly burned, in a plane crash. Heather Armstrong was writing about work when she was blindsided by postpartum depression and blogged her way through a psychiatric hospitalization. The comic Daphne Brogdon's blog was about her blended family, until she lost her life savings to Bernie Madoff.
docs.abstract: How to help a mother who has supported others and now needs some support herself?
docs.snippet: How to help a mother who has supported others and now needs some support herself?

docs.lead_paragraph: The nonprofit group Exhale offers free counseling to any woman who has had an abortion and has resolutely tried to avoid politics. Now, politics has come to it.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a federal survey, 13 percent of pregnant women had high levels of cotinine, a biological indicator of tobacco exposure — and almost a quarter of them lied about it.

headline.seo: Many Pregnant Smokers Lie About Their Habit, Study Finds
headline.main: Smoking for Two, and Lying About It
headline.print_headline: HAVING A BABY: Smoking for Two, and Lying About It

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) DEADLIEST EARTHQUAKES In an evening of programming devoted to Haiti on the eve of the one-year anniversary of the earthquake that killed more than 200,000 in the capital, Port-au-Prince, this ''Nova'' episode follows a team of American geologists as they enter the country in the earthquake's immediate aftermath to help determine what caused it, as well as the risks of a new one. A month later ''Nova'' also tags along as the geologists travel to Chile, where a quake 100 times more powerful generated a tsunami -- and where new data could help prevent future disasters. ''Battle for Haiti,'' a ''Frontline'' episode that examines gang leaders' efforts to reassert control in the ravaged capital, will be broadcast at 9 on Channel 13 and at 10 on Channel 49; ''Children of Haiti,'' an ''Independent Lens'' installment that follows three teenage boys over three years, will be shown at 10 on Channel 13 and at 11 on Channel 49. 10 A.M. (ABC) RACHAEL RAY Segments look at a quick face lift without surgery and how to minimize wrinkles and dark circles. Also, tips from Oprah Winfrey's makeup artist.
